member.name: T:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView
member.summary: DS multi direction scroll view.

members.member: * Flag to indicate that we are moving focus ourselves. This is so the * code that watches for focus changes initiated outside this TwoDScrollView * knows that it does not have to do anything.
* Position of the last motion event.
* True when the layout has changed but the traversal has not come through yet. * Ideally the view hierarchy would keep track of this for us.

* The child to give focus to in the event that a child has requested focus while the * layout is dirty. This prevents the scroll from being wrong if the child has not been * laid out before requesting focus.

* True if the user is currently dragging this TwoDScrollView around. This is * not the same as 'is being flinged', which can be checked by * mScroller.isFinished() (flinging begins when the user lifts his finger).
* Determines speed during touch scrolling
* Whether arrow scrolling is animated.

member.name: P:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView.ContentOffset
member.summary: Gets the content offset.

member.name: P:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView.Frame
member.summary: Gets the frame.

member.name: P:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView.MaxScrollAmountVertical
member.summary: The maximum amount this scroll view will scroll in response to an arrow event.

member.name: P:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView.MaxScrollAmountHorizontal
member.summary: The maximum amount this scroll view will scroll in response to an arrow event.

member.name: P:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView.CanScroll
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this instance can scroll.
member.value: true if this instance can scroll; otherwise, false.

members.member: * You can call this function yourself to have the scroll view perform * scrolling from a key event, just as if the event had been dispatched to * it by the view hierarchy. * * @param event The key event to execute. * @return Return true if the event was handled, else false.

* Finds the next focusable component that fits in this View's bounds * (excluding fading edges) pretending that this View's top is located at * the parameter top. * * @param topFocus look for a candidate is the one at the top of the bounds * if topFocus is true, or at the bottom of the bounds if topFocus is * false * @param top the top offset of the bounds in which a focusable must be * found (the fading edge is assumed to start at this position) * @param preferredFocusable the View that has highest priority and will be * returned if it is within my bounds (null is valid) * @return the next focusable component in the bounds or null if none can be * found

member.name: M:DSoft.UI.DSMultiDirectionScrollView.FindFocusableViewInBounds(System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds the focusable view in bounds.
member.param: If set to true top focus.
If set to true left focus.

members.member:
*
Handles scrolling in response to a "home/end" shortcut press. This * method will scroll the view to the top or bottom and give the focus * to the topmost/bottommost component in the new visible area. If no * component is a good candidate for focus, this scrollview reclaims the * focus. * * @param direction the scroll direction: {@link android.view.View#FOCUS_UP} * to go the top of the view or * {@link android.view.View#FOCUS_DOWN} to go the bottom * @return true if the key event is consumed by this method, false otherwise

*
Scrolls the view to make the area defined by top and * bottom visible. This method attempts to give the focus * to a component visible in this area. If no component can be focused in * the new visible area, the focus is reclaimed by this scrollview. * * @param direction the scroll direction: {@link android.view.View#FOCUS_UP} * to go upward * {@link android.view.View#FOCUS_DOWN} to downward * @param top the top offset of the new area to be made visible * @param bottom the bottom offset of the new area to be made visible * @return true if the key event is consumed by this method, false otherwise

* Handle scrolling in response to an up or down arrow click. * * @param direction The direction corresponding to the arrow key that was * pressed * @return True if we consumed the event, false otherwise
* Smooth scroll by a Y delta * * @param delta the number of pixels to scroll by on the Y axis
* Like {@link View#scrollBy}, but scroll smoothly instead of immediately. * * @param dx the number of pixels to scroll by on the X axis * @param dy the number of pixels to scroll by on the Y axis
* Like {@link #scrollTo}, but scroll smoothly instead of immediately. * * @param x the position where to scroll on the X axis * @param y the position where to scroll on the Y axis
* Scrolls the view to the given child. * * @param child the View to scroll to

* If rect is off screen, scroll just enough to get it (or at least the * first screen size chunk of it) on screen. * * @param rect The rectangle. * @param immediate True to scroll immediately without animation * @return true if scrolling was performed

* Compute the amount to scroll in the Y direction in order to get * a rectangle completely on the screen (or, if taller than the screen, * at least the first screen size chunk of it). * * @param rect The rect. * @return The scroll delta.

* When looking for focus in children of a scroll view, need to be a little * more careful not to give focus to something that is scrolled off screen. * * This is more expensive than the default {@link android.view.ViewGroup} * implementation, otherwise this behavior might have been made the default.
* Return true if child is an descendant of parent, (or equal to the parent).

* Fling the scroll view * * @param velocityY The initial velocity in the Y direction. Positive * numbers mean that the finger/curor is moving down the screen, * which means we want to scroll towards the top.

member.name: M:DSoft.UI.Grid.Views.Collections.DSGridRowViewCollection.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resource used by the object.
member.remarks: Call when you are finished using the . The method leaves the in an unusable state. After calling , you must release all references to the so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the was occupying.

member.name: M:DSoft.UI.Views.DSAbsoluteLayout.ShouldDelayChildPressedState
member.Docs: Return true if the pressed state should be delayed for children or descendants of this ViewGroup.
member.remarks: Return true if the pressed state should be delayed for children or descendants of this ViewGroup. Generally, this should be done for containers that can scroll, such as a List. This prevents the pressed state from appearing when the user is actually trying to scroll the content. The default implementation returns true for compatibility reasons. Subclasses that do not scroll should generally override this method and return false.
member.summary: Shoulds the state of the delay child pressed.
member.returns: true, if delay child pressed state was shoulded, false otherwise.
